docs.lead_paragraph: HISTORY may judge it a little odd that after the greatest accrual of private wealth in a century, the United States decided to give its richest citizens a giant tax break. But in truth, favoring the wealthy has become a habit in Washington for a couple of decades, and may help explain why so many average Americans feel the federal government does not do much for them. Even President Bill Clinton adopted policy after policy that disproportionately benefited those who made the most money. I am referring to what are commonly called ''tax expenditures.'' These are credits to and deductions from federal income taxes that usually reward some kinds of spending or saving. When businesses deduct the health care benefits they pay employees, for example, it is a sizable loss of revenue to the government. In effect, it is a government expenditure that subsidizes health insurance for the employed -- usually those employed by big corporations. The same is true of deductions for pensions and countless special corporate benefits, like accelerated depreciation.

headline.main: Economic Scene; In America, to the richest go the biggest tax benefits. So what else is new?

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush will sign his long-promised tax cut today. But conservatives shouldn't break out the champagne just yet, nor should liberals start taking their antidepressants. Passing the cuts was easy. Mesmerized by projections of mountainous surpluses, few legislators could say no. But Congress and the president have turned their attention to crafting solutions to the nation's other problems, and now the real battle over taxes will begin. When the dust from this struggle settles, much of the relief the tax bill promises for later this decade is likely to be delayed, scaled back or repealed altogether.

headline.main: Don't Count on That Tax Cut

docs.lead_paragraph: Life is not about how you go down but about how you get up, Twyla Tharp said in a brief speech on Sunday afternoon at the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church. Then she strode over to embrace Homer Avila, who sat in the front row, his purple plastic crutches propped jauntily beside him. Ms. Tharp and her dancers were among 12 companies and individuals who participated in ''One Step Forward,'' a benefit for a new fund of the same name created by the Manhattan-based New York Foundation for the Arts to help Mr. Avila and others like him with sudden catastrophic health emergencies. It was an afternoon of inspired dance and inspiring commentary.

docs.lead_paragraph: New York's highest court ruled today that the state had violated the state and federal Constitutions by denying Medicaid benefits to thousands of needy legal immigrants. The state policy applied to immigrants who arrived in this country after August 1996. At that time, under a far-reaching new welfare law, Congress barred immigrants who came after that from availing themselves of a range of federally financed government benefits. It was left to the states to decide whether to cover the cost of those benefits, including Medicaid, the health insurance program for the poor. At the insistence of Gov. George E. Pataki, the state decided not to, and state legislation was passed to conform to the federal act.

headline.main: Medicaid Curb For Immigrants Is Ruled Illegal

docs.lead_paragraph: A top federal health official said today that the Bush administration would try to double the enrollment of Medicare beneficiaries in health maintenance organizations within four years. The official, Thomas A. Scully, said he wanted to have 30 percent of elderly patients in managed care by 2005. At present, slightly more than 14 percent of the 40 million Medicare beneficiaries -- 5.7 million people -- are in such health plans.

docs.lead_paragraph: Before AIDS, there was no breast cancer walk in Central Park. Babies needing foster parents languished in hospitals for weeks, sometimes years. Clinics doled out medicines and sent the sick on their way, rarely looking at what it was in their lives that helped to make them ill. In many ways, New York City after AIDS is somewhat like America after World War II -- a place physically unscathed yet socially transformed, missing slices of entire generations of its citizens, its lasting effects at times concrete and at others evanescent.

headline.main: A New York Vastly Altered by AIDS

docs.abstract: Special report, AIDS at 20: A City Transformed, examines ways in which AIDS epidemic has transformed social fabric of New York City; epidemic, which has killed 75,000 New Yorkers or nearly 20 percent of Americans who have died from disease since diagnosis 20 years ago, has altered city in ways both so widespread and subtle that shifts are no longer consciously associated with disease; morphed insurance, fashion, philanthropic, healthcare, real estate and music industries and altered hip quotient among social set's choices in entertainment and charitable causes; has increased awareness of other illnesses, such that system of coordinated care hospitals devised to deal with disease has trickled down to management of other illnesses; has brought immediacy to social services that simply did not exist before, but whose legacy lingers; has made gays political constituency in city, one that rivals traditional voting blocs, like religious Jews and African-Americans in some neighbohoods; charts; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George Pataki brought home an important prize last week from his Republican allies in Washington. The Bush administration waived certain Medicaid rules that cleared the way for a plan that New York calls Family Health Plus, aimed at the state's working poor. The plan will help fill another gap in health coverage by expanding the Child Health Plus program that has successfully provided medical insurance for children. This expansion could offer health insurance to as many as 620,000 adults who cannot now afford coverage or who do not qualify for Medicaid, in most cases because their income is above the poverty level. The state is expected to take applications in September and begin offering the new coverage in October. That is a tight deadline, but it is worth the effort as health care costs soar and public health services diminish. The program is designed to offer free health insurance for families earning 150 percent of the poverty level. For thousands of working-class families earning more than that, the state has begun offering a subsidy to provide low-cost health insurance premiums as well.
